instructions.text:
Submit your answers to the following questions: 

  • Go back to your product roadmap and try to break down your user stories (from the previous exercise) into more concrete and specific work items.

    • Revise your user stories/tasks again
    • Break them into smaller, more specific tasks
    • Revise the order and make adjustments
    • Decide how much work you can achieve in a specific amount of time, i.e., 2 weeks
  • Reflect on the status of your current product. In what stage of prototyping is it in? Is it still in the early stages with only a sketch, a draft, or has it progressed to its final shape? 
  • Are there any usability testing techniques that you have tried before?
    • What usability testing techniques would you like to try with your product?
    • Select any technique to test your product with users. The purpose of testing is to gather feedback about your product performance.
    • Document all feedback you got. It could be in the form of user stories.
    • Review the feedback and make improvements.
  • Select any prompt from above and brainstorm it with your team.
    Here is an example.
    • Set the stage: Start by explaining the purpose of the retrospective and introduce the "Start/Stop/Continue" framework (or any of the prompts identified above). Remind everyone that the goal is to identify areas of improvement for the team, and establish some ground rules, such as encouraging open and honest communication and making sure everyone has a chance to speak.
    • Brainstorm: Have each team member brainstorm ideas for what the team should start doing, stop doing, and continue doing. Encourage them to think broadly and come up with as many ideas as possible.
    • Group ideas: Once everyone has shared their ideas, group similar ideas together. This can be done using sticky notes or a whiteboard. Try to identify patterns or themes that emerge.
    • Discuss and prioritize: As a group, discuss the ideas that have been generated and prioritize them based on their potential impact and feasibility. Focus on the ideas that are most likely to make a significant difference to the team's performance.
    • Create an action plan: Based on the ideas that have been prioritized, create an action plan that outlines what the team will start doing, stop doing, and continue doing next time.

Submit your answers to the activities covered in Module 1:

  • What product are you working on?
  • Submit your product value statement.

Submit your answers to the following questions by uploading your word document:

  • What problem are you trying to solve?
    • Go to Reframe the Problem(this link opens in a new window/tab)  and follow the instructions to write your problem statement.
    • Note: To help you get started, reflect on the 4 Ws (who, why, what, and where) to answer the question.
  • What methods have you used to collect data? What methods do you want to try?
  • In the previous activities, you identified a product you are currently or planning to work on, conducted user research (hopefully), and stated the problem you are trying to solve. Instructions:
  • Write your product vision statement.
    • If you need guidance on how to structure your product vision, go to step 1 below.
  • Note: There is no right or wrong way to write product vision. What matters is that the team collectively agree on a product vision.

The table below helps you brainstorm the needed information to write a product vision statement.

Step 1: Complete the table.

Problem framing by users, needs, problems, product, and goal.
Problem framing
Users: [who are the users of the product you are building]
Needs: [think about your users' needs]
Problems: [What do you think the problem is?]
Product: [What does your product look like]
Goals (what, why, who, and how): [What is the purpose of your product]

Step 2: Synthesize your answers into a statement.

The templates below provide you with two structures to practice writing your product vision. 

“A [what] that will [why] for [who] by [how].”

Example: A high-quality collaborative video-conferencing tool with a built-in accessibility checker that ensures compliance with accessibility standards that will streamline collaboration for public servants and professionals who work from home, by notifying users of potential issues.

Template 2:

Example 2 of problem framing.
For, ... [target user]
who, ... [statement of need or opportunity]
the .... [product name]
is a ....  [product category)
that .... [reason to use]
by .... . [how]
Unlike, [other products]
this product, [what is different]

Example: For public servants and professionals who work from home, the Teams Whiteboard is a high-quality collaborative video-conferencing tool with a built-in accessibility checker that ensures compliance with accessibility standards by notifying users of any potential issues. Unlike other collaborative tools, Teams Whiteboard offers a proactive approach to accessibility, identifying potential issues and highlighting which features are not in compliance, ensuring everyone can contribute.

Submit your answers to the following questions:

  • Collect and write user stories by interviewing users.

    If you can't interview users, reflect on the feedback you have collected from your users about your product.

    • Write 2-4 user stories (feedback that users provide captured in their own words). 
    • Choose one user story and write 2-3 acceptance criteria (how would you know that your user story is complete) 
  • On a whiteboard or paper, draw the quadrants.
    • Label high on the top of the Y-axis and low at the bottom.
    • Label high on the left of the X-axis and low on the right
    • Choose a prioritization method (RICE, MoSCoW, PACE, the Power Matrix, etc.) that works best for your product.
    • Assign a category for each quadrant. For example, if you're using RICE, the categories could be Reach, Impact, Confidence, and Effort. If you're using MoSCoW, the categories could be Must-Have, Should-Have, Could-Have, and Won't-Have.
    • Gather your team (if you have one, if not try it alone) and review the user stories that you want to prioritize.
    • Once you've reviewed the user stories, place them on the whiteboard in the quadrant that corresponds to their category. For example, if a user story has a high impact and low effort, it would go in the top-right quadrant if you're using RICE, or the Must-Have quadrant if you're using MoSCoW.
    • Repeat this process for all user stories until they are all placed on the whiteboard.
    • Number the user stories in the top right hand corner in order of priority.
  • In this activity, you will learn how to plan your evaluation strategy.
  • Follow the steps below:
    • Go back to your product vision: define the product goals and the product value you want to deliver.
    • List all the potential / desired outcomes (the refined ones after conducting user research and defining the problem)
    • Brainstorm potential metrics
      • setting hypothesis is a good starting point. What hypotheses are you testing?
      • mapping the user journey to your goals can also help you identify your goals and your metrics
      • start small and keep it simple (focus on a limited number of outcomes)
      • Select metrics that are relevant to your goals
      • Decide which metrics are leading and which ones are lagging (this step is optional)
        • To help you determine whether a metric is a leading or lagging indicator, ask the following questions:
        • Does the metric measure a past or current event, or a future potential outcome?
          • If it measures a past or current event, it is likely a lagging indicator.
          • If it measures a future potential outcome, it is likely a leading indicator.
        • Does the metric provide insight into future trends, or measure the success of completed actions?
          • If it provides insight into future trends, it is likely a leading indicator.
          • If it measures the success of completed actions, it is likely a lagging indicator.
        • Does the metric focus on activities and events that can impact future outcomes, or on measuring the results of past activities and events?
          • If it focuses on activities and events that can impact future outcomes, it is likely a leading indicator.
          • If it focuses on measuring the results of past activities and events, it is likely a lagging indicator.
        • Ensure that leading and lagging indicators complement each other to provide a comprehensive view of product performance
  • Follow the instructions below to help you get started with your evaluation strategy.
    • Use AAARR and HEART frameworks to identify goals that are relevant to you.
    • Decide what metrics you want to use.
    • Set your validation criteria
    • Frame them using the structure: We believe that [goal]...To verify that, we will [method]...And measure [metric]...We are right if [result]...
    • For more examples, take a look at the Test Card
